1000005%%Esther%%OT%%6%%14%%And while they were yet talking with him, came the king's chamberlains, and hasted to bring Haman to the banquet that Esther had prepared.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%7%%1%%So the king and Haman came to banquet with Esther the queen.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%7%%2%%And the king said again to Esther on the second day at the banquet of wine, What is thy petition, queen Esther? and it shall be granted thee: and what is thy request? and it shall be performed, even to the half of the kingdom.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%7%%3%%Then Esther the queen answered and said, If I have found favor in thy sight, O king, and if it shall please the king, let my life be given me at my petition, and my people at my request:
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%7%%4%%For we are sold, I and my people, to be destroyed, to be slain, and to perish. But if we had been sold for bond-men and bond-women, I had held my tongue, although the enemy could not countervail the king's damage.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%7%%5%%Then the king Ahasuerus answered and said to Esther the queen, Who is he, and where is he, that durst presume in his heart to do so?
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%7%%6%%And Esther said, The adversary and enemy is this wicked Haman. Then Haman was afraid before the king and the queen.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%7%%7%%And the king arising from the banquet of wine in his wrath went into the palace-garden: and Haman stood up to make request for his life to Esther the queen; for he saw that there was evil determined against him by the king.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%7%%8%%Then the king returned out of the palace-garden into the place of the banquet of wine; and Haman had fallen upon the bed on which Esther was. Then said the king, Will he force the queen also before me in the house? As the word went out of the king's mouth, they covered Haman's face.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%7%%9%%And Harbonah, one of the chamberlains, said before the king, Behold also, the gallows fifty cubits high, which Haman had made for Mordecai, who had spoken good for the king, standeth in the house of Haman. Then the king said, Hang him upon it.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%7%%10%%So they hanged Haman on the gallows that he had prepared for Mordecai. Then was the king's wrath pacified.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%1%%On that day the king Ahasuerus gave the house of Haman, the Jews' enemy, to Esther the queen. And Mordecai came before the king; for Esther had told what he was to her.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%2%%And the king took off his ring which he had taken from Haman, and gave it to Mordecai. And Esther set Mordecai over the house of Haman.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%3%%And Esther spoke yet again before the king, and fell down at his feet, and besought him with tears to put away the mischief of Haman the Agagite, and his device that he had devised against the Jews.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%4%%Then the king held out the golden scepter towards Esther. So Esther arose, and stood before the king,
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%5%%And said, If it shall please the king, and if I have found favor in his sight, and the thing shall seem right before the king, and I am pleasing in his eyes, let it be written to reverse the letters devised by Haman the son of Hammedatha the Agagite, which he wrote to destroy the Jews who are in all the king's provinces:
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%6%%For how can I endure to see the evil that will come to my people? or how can I endure to see the destruction of my kindred?
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%7%%Then the king Ahasuerus said to Esther the queen and to Mordecai the Jew, Behold, I have given Esther the house of Haman, and him they have hanged upon the gallows, because he laid his hand upon the Jews.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%8%%Write ye also for the Jews, as it pleaseth you, in the king's name, and seal it with the king's ring: for the writing which is written in the king's name, and sealed with the king's ring, no man may reverse.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%9%%Then were the king's scribes called at that time in the third month, that is, the month Sivan, on the three and twentieth day of it; and it was written, according to all that Mordecai commanded, to the Jews, and to the lieutenants, and the deputies and rulers of the provinces which are from India to Cush, a hundred twenty and seven provinces, to every province according to the writing of it, and to every people after their language, and to the Jews according to their writing, and according to their language.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%10%%And he wrote in the king Ahasuerus's name, and sealed it with the king's ring, and sent letters by posts on horseback, and riders on mules, camels, and young dromedaries:
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%11%%In which the king granted the Jews who were in every city to assemble, and to stand for their life, to destroy, to slay, and to cause to perish, all the power of the people and province that would assault them, both little ones and women, and to take the spoil of them for a prey,
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%12%%Upon one day in all the provinces of king Ahasuerus, namely, upon the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, which is the month Adar,
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%13%%The copy of the writing for a commandment, to be given in every province was published to all people, and that the Jews should be ready against that day to avenge themselves on their enemies.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%14%%So the posts that rode upon mules and camels went out, being hastened and pressed on by the king's commandment. And the decree was given at Shushan the palace.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%15%%And Mordecai went out from the presence of the king in royal apparel of blue and white, and with a great crown of gold, and with a garment of fine linen and purple: and the city of Shushan rejoiced, and was glad:
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%16%%The Jews had light, and gladness, and joy, and honor.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%8%%17%%And in every province, and in every city, whithersoever the king's commandment and his decree came, the Jews had joy and gladness, a feast and a good day. And many of the people of the land became Jews; for the fear of the Jews fell upon them.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%1%%Now in the twelfth month, that is, the month Adar, on the thirteenth day of the same, when the king's commandment and his decree drew near to be put in execution, in the day that the enemies of the Jews hoped to have power over them, (though it was turned to the contrary, that the Jews had rule over them that hated them;)
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%2%%The Jews assembled in their cities throughout all the provinces of the king Ahasuerus, to lay hand on such as sought their hurt: and no man could withstand them; for the fear of them fell upon all people.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%3%%And all the rulers of the provinces, and the lieutenants, and the deputies, and officers of the king helped the Jews; because the fear of Mordecai fell upon them.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%4%%For Mordecai was great in the king's house, and his fame went out throughout all the provinces: for this man Mordecai became greater and greater.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%5%%Thus the Jews smote all their enemies with the stroke of the sword, and slaughter, and destruction, and did what they would to those that hated them.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%6%%And in Shushan the palace the Jews slew and destroyed five hundred men.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%7%%And Parshandatha, and Dalphon, and Aspatha,
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%8%%And Poratha, and Adalia, and Aridatha,
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%9%%And Parmashta, and Arisai, and Aridai, and Vajezatha,
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%10%%The ten sons of Haman the son of Hammedatha, the enemy of the Jews, they slew; but on the spoil they laid not their hand.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%11%%On that day the number of those that were slain in Shushan the palace was brought before the king.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%12%%And the king said to Esther the queen, the Jews have slain and destroyed five hundred men in Shushan the palace, and the ten sons of Haman; what have they done in the rest of the king's provinces? now what is thy petition? and it shall be granted thee: or what is thy request further? and it shall be done.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%13%%Then said Esther, If it shall please the king, let it be granted to the Jews who are in Shushan to do to-morrow also according to this day's decree, and let Haman's ten sons be hanged upon the gallows.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%14%%And the king commanded it so to be done: and the decree was given at Shushan; and they hanged Haman's ten sons.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%15%%For the Jews that were in Shushan assembled on the fourteenth day also of the month Adar, and slew three hundred men at Shushan; but on the prey they laid not their hand.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%16%%But the other Jews that were in the king's provinces assembled, and stood for their lives, and had rest from their enemies, and slew of their foes seventy and five thousand, (but they laid not their hands on the prey.)
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%17%%On the thirteenth day of the month Adar; and on the fourteenth day of the same they rested, and made it a day of feasting and gladness.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%18%%But the Jews that were at Shushan assembled on the thirteenth day of the month, and on the fourteenth of it: and on the fifteenth day of the same they rested, and made it a day of feasting and gladness.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%19%%Therefore the Jews of the villages, that dwelt in the unwalled towns, made the fourteenth day of the month Adar a day of gladness and feasting, and a good day, and of sending portions one to another.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%20%%And Mordecai wrote these things, and sent letters to all the Jews that were in all the provinces of the king Ahasuerus, both nigh and far,
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%21%%To establish this among them, that they should keep the fourteenth day of the month Adar, and the fifteenth day of the same, yearly,
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%22%%As the days in which the Jews rested from their enemies, and the month which was turned to them from sorrow to joy, and from mourning into a good day, that they should make them days of feasting and joy, and of sending portions one to another, and gifts to the poor.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%23%%And the Jews undertook to do as they had begun, and as Mordecai had written to them;
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%24%%Because Haman the son of Hammedatha, the Agagite, the enemy of all the Jews, had devised against the Jews to destroy them, and had cast Pur, that is, the lot, to consume them, and to destroy them;
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%25%%But when Esther came before the king, he commanded by letters that his wicked device, which he devised against the Jews, should return upon his own head, and that he and his sons should be hanged on the gallows.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%26%%Wherefore they called these days Purim after the name of Pur. Therefore for all the words of this letter, and of that which they had seen concerning this matter, and which had come to them,
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%27%%The Jews ordained, and took upon them, and upon their seed, and upon all such as joined themselves to them, so as it should not fail, that they would keep these two days according to their writing, and according to their appointed time every year;
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%28%%And that these days should be remembered and kept throughout every generation, every family, every province, and every city; and that these days of Purim should not fail from among the Jews, nor the memorial of them perish from their seed.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%29%%Then Esther the queen, the daughter of Abihail, and Mordecai the Jew, wrote with all authority, to confirm this second letter of Purim.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%30%%And he sent the letters to all the Jews, to the hundred twenty and seven provinces of the kingdom of Ahasuerus, with words of peace and truth,
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%31%%To confirm these days of Purim in their times appointed, according as Mordecai the Jew and Esther the queen had enjoined them, and as they had decreed for themselves and for their seed, the matters of the fastings and their cry.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%9%%32%%And the decree of Esther confirmed these matters of Purim; and it was written in the book.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%10%%1%%And the king Ahasuerus laid a tribute upon the land, and upon the isles of the sea.
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%10%%2%%And all the acts of his power and of his might, and the declaration of the greatness of Mordecai, to which the king advanced him, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Media and Persia?
1000005%%Esther%%OT%%10%%3%%For Mordecai the Jew was next to king Ahasuerus, and great among the Jews, and accepted by the multitude of his brethren, seeking the wealth of his people, and speaking peace to all his seed.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%1%%There was a man in the land of Uz, whose name was Job; and that man was perfect and upright, and one that feared God, and shunned evil.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%2%%And there were born to him seven sons and three daughters.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%3%%His substance also was seven thousand sheep, and three thousand camels, and five hundred yoke of oxen, and five hundred she-asses, and a very great household; so that this man was the greatest of all the men of the east.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%4%%And his sons went and feasted in their houses, every one his day; and sent and called for their three sisters to eat and to drink with them.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%5%%And it was so, when the days of their feasting were ended, that Job sent and sanctified them, and rose early in the morning, and offered burnt-offerings according to the number of them all; for Job said, It may be that my sons have sinned, and cursed God in their hearts. Thus did Job continually.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%6%%Now there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the LORD, and Satan came also among them.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%7%%And the LORD said to Satan, Whence comest thou? Then Satan answered the LORD, and said, From going to and fro on the earth, and from walking up and down upon it.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%8%%And the LORD said to Satan, Hast thou considered my servant Job, that there is none like him on the earth, a perfect and an upright man, one that feareth God, and shunneth evil?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%9%%Then Satan answered the LORD, and said, Doth Job fear God for naught?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%10%%Hast not thou made a hedge about him, and about his house, and about all that he hath on every side? thou hast blessed the work of his hands, and his substance is increased in the land.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%11%%But put forth thy hand now, and touch all that he hath, and he will curse thee to thy face.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%12%%And the LORD said to Satan, Behold, all that he hath is in thy power; only upon himself put not forth thy hand. So Satan went forth from the presence of the LORD.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%13%%And there was a day when his sons and his daughters were eating and drinking wine in their eldest brother's house:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%14%%And there came a messenger to Job, and said, The oxen were plowing, and the asses feeding beside them:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%15%%And the Sabeans fell upon them, and took them away; yes, they have slain the servants with the edge of the sword; and I only have escaped alone to tell thee.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%16%%While he was yet speaking, there came also another, and said, The fire of God hath fallen from heaven, and hath burned up the sheep and the servants, and consumed them; and I only have escaped alone to tell thee.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%17%%While he was yet speaking, there came also another, and said, The Chaldeans made three bands, and fell upon the camels, and have carried them away, yes, and slain the servants with the edge of the sword; and I only have escaped alone to tell thee.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%18%%While he was yet speaking, there came also another, and said, Thy sons and thy daughters were eating and drinking wine in their eldest brother's house:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%19%%And behold, there came a great wind from the wilderness, and smote the four corners of the house, and it fell upon the young men, and they are dead; and I only have escaped alone to tell thee.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%20%%Then Job arose, and rent his mantle, and shaved his head, and fell upon the ground, and worshiped,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%21%%And said, Naked came I from my mother's womb, and naked shall I return thither: The LORD gave, and the LORD hath taken away; blessed be the name of the LORD.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%1%%22%%In all this Job sinned not, nor charged God foolishly.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%2%%1%%Again there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the LORD, and Satan came also among them to present himself before the LORD.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%2%%2%%And the LORD said to Satan, Whence comest thou? and Satan answered the LORD, and said, From going to and fro on the earth, and from walking up and down upon it.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%2%%3%%And the LORD said to Satan, Hast thou considered my servant Job, that there is none like him on the earth, a perfect and an upright man, one that feareth God, and shunneth evil? and still he holdeth fast his integrity, although thou movedst me against him, to destroy him without cause.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%2%%4%%And Satan answered the LORD, and said, Skin for skin, even, all that a man hath will he give for his life.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%2%%5%%But put forth thy hand now, and touch his bone and his flesh, and he will curse thee to thy face.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%2%%6%%And the LORD said to Satan, Behold, he is in thy hand; but save his life.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%2%%7%%So Satan went forth from the presence of the LORD, and smote Job with sore boils from the sole of his foot to his crown.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%2%%8%%And he took him a potsherd to scrape himself with it; and he sat down among the ashes.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%2%%9%%Then said his wife to him, Dost thou still retain thy integrity? curse God, and die.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%2%%10%%But he said to her, Thou speakest as one of the foolish women speaketh. What? shall we receive good at the hand of God, and shall we not receive evil? In all this did not Job sin with his lips.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%2%%11%%Now when Job's three friends heard of all this evil that had come upon him, they came every one from his own place; Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite; for they had made an appointment together to come to mourn with him, and to comfort him.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%2%%12%%And when they lifted up their eyes afar off, and knew him not, they raised their voice, and wept; and they rent every one his mantle, and sprinkled dust upon their heads towards heaven.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%2%%13%%So they sat down with him upon the ground seven days and seven nights, and none spoke a word to him: for they saw that his grief was very great.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%1%%After this Job opened his mouth, and cursed his day.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%2%%And Job spoke, and said,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%3%%Let the day perish in which I was born, and the night in which it was said, There is a mail child conceived.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%4%%Let that day be darkness; let not God regard it from above, neither let the light shine upon it.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%5%%Let darkness and the shades of death stain it; let a cloud dwell upon it; let the blackness of the day terrify it.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%6%%As for that night, let darkness seize upon it; let it not be joined to the days of the year, let it not come into the number of the months.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%7%%Lo, let that night be solitary, let no joyful voice come therein.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%8%%Let them curse it that curse the day, who are ready to raise up their mourning.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%9%%Let the stars of its twilight be dark; let it look for light, but have none; neither let it see the dawning of the day:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%10%%Because it prevented not my birth, nor hid sorrow from my eyes.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%11%%Why died I not from the womb? why did I not expire at the time of my birth?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%12%%Why did the knees receive me? or why the breasts that I should be nursed?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%13%%For now should I have lain still and been quiet, I should have slept: then had I been at rest,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%14%%With kings and counselors of the earth, who built desolate places for themselves;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%15%%Or with princes that had gold, who filled their houses with silver:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%16%%Or as a hidden untimely birth I had not been; as infants which never saw light.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%17%%There the wicked cease from troubling; and there the weary are at rest.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%18%%There the prisoners rest together; they hear not the voice of the oppressor.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%19%%The small and great are there; and the servant is free from his master.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%20%%Why is light given to him that is in misery, and life to the bitter in soul;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%21%%Who long for death, but it cometh not; and dig for it more than for hid treasures;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%22%%Who rejoice exceedingly, and are glad, when they can find the grave?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%23%%Why is light given to a man whose way is hid, and whom God hath hedged in?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%24%%For my sighing cometh before I eat, and my roarings are poured out like the waters.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%25%%For the thing which I greatly feared hath come upon me, and that which I dreaded hath come to me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%3%%26%%I was not in safety, neither had I rest, neither was I quiet; yet trouble came.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%1%%Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%2%%If we essay to commune with thee, wilt thou be grieved? but who can refrain from speaking?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%3%%Behold, thou hast instructed many, and thou hast strengthened the weak hands.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%4%%Thy words have upheld him that was falling, and thou hast strengthened the feeble knees.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%5%%But now it hath come upon thee, and thou faintest; it toucheth thee, and thou art troubled.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%6%%Is not this thy fear, thy confidence, thy hope, and the uprightness of thy ways?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%7%%Remember, I pray thee, who ever perished, being innocent? or where were the righteous cut off;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%8%%Even as I have seen, they that plow iniquity, and sow wickedness, reap the same.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%9%%By the blast of God they perish, and by the breath of his nostrils are they consumed.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%10%%The roaring of the lion, and the voice of the fierce lion, and the teeth of the young lions, are broken.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%11%%The old lion perisheth for lack of prey, and the stout lion's whelps are scattered abroad.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%12%%Now a thing was secretly brought to me, and my ear received a small sound of it.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%13%%In thoughts from the visions of the night, when deep sleep falleth on men.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%14%%Fear came upon me, and trembling, which made all my bones to shake.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%15%%Then a spirit passed before my face; the hair of my flesh stood up:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%16%%It stood still, but I could not discern its form: an image was before my eyes, there was silence, and I heard a voice, saying,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%17%%Shall mortal man be more just than God? shall a man be more pure than his maker?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%18%%Behold, he put no trust in his servants; and his angels he charged with folly:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%19%%How much less in them that dwell in houses of clay, whose foundation is in the dust, who are crushed before the moth?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%20%%They are destroyed from morning to evening: they perish for ever without any regarding it.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%4%%21%%Doth not their excellence which is in them depart? they die, even without wisdom.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%1%%Call now, if there is any that will answer thee; and to which of the saints wilt thou turn?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%2%%For wrath killeth the foolish man, and envy slayeth the silly one.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%3%%I have seen the foolish taking root: but suddenly I cursed his habitation.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%4%%His children are far from safety, and they are crushed in the gate, neither is there any to deliver them.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%5%%Whose harvest the hungry eateth up, and taketh it even out of the thorns, and the robber swalloweth up their substance.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%6%%Although affliction cometh not forth from the dust, neither doth trouble spring out of the ground;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%7%%Yet man is born to trouble, as the sparks fly upward.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%8%%I would seek to God, and to God would I commit my cause:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%9%%Who doeth great things and unsearchable; wonderful things without number:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%10%%Who giveth rain upon the earth, and sendeth waters upon the fields:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%11%%To set on high those that are low: that those who mourn may be exalted to safety.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%12%%He disappointeth the devices of the crafty, so that their hands cannot perform their enterprise.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%13%%He taketh the wise in their own craftiness: and the counsel of the froward is carried headlong.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%14%%They meet with darkness in the day-time, and grope in the noon-day as in the night.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%15%%But he saveth the poor from the sword, from their mouth, and from the hand of the mighty.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%16%%So the poor hath hope, and iniquity stoppeth her mouth.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%17%%Behold, happy is the man whom God correcteth: therefore despise not thou the chastening of the Almighty:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%18%%For he maketh sore, and bindeth up: he woundeth, and his hands make whole.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%19%%He will deliver thee in six troubles: yea, in seven there shall no evil touch thee.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%20%%In famine he will redeem thee from death: and in war from the power of the sword.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%21%%Thou shalt be hid from the scourge of the tongue: neither shalt thou be afraid of destruction when it cometh.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%22%%At destruction and famine thou shalt laugh: neither shalt thou be afraid of the beasts of the earth.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%23%%For thou shalt be in league with the stones of the field: and the beasts of the field shall be at peace with thee.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%24%%And thou shalt know that thy tabernacle will be in peace; and thou shalt visit thy habitation, and shalt not sin.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%25%%Thou shalt know also that thy seed will be great, and thy offspring as the grass of the earth.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%26%%Thou shalt come to thy grave in a full age, as a shock of corn cometh in in its season.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%5%%27%%Lo this, we have searched it, so it is; hear it, and know thou it for thy good.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%1%%But Job answered and said,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%2%%Oh that my grief were thoroughly weighed, and my calamity laid in the balances together!
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%3%%For now it would be heavier than the sand of the sea: therefore my words are swallowed up.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%4%%For the arrows of the Almighty are within me, the poison of which drinketh up my spirit: the terrors of God set themselves in array against me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%5%%Doth the wild ass bray when he hath grass? or loweth the ox over his fodder?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%6%%Can that which is unsavory be eaten without salt? or is there any taste in the white of an egg?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%7%%The things that my soul refused to touch are as my sorrowful food.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%8%%Oh that I might have my request; and that God would grant me the thing that I long for!
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%9%%Even that it would please God to destroy me; that he would let loose his hand, and cut me off!
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%10%%Then should I yet have comfort; yes, I would harden myself in sorrow: let him not spare; for I have not concealed the words of the Holy One.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%11%%What is my strength, that I should hope? and what is my end, that I should prolong my life?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%12%%Is my strength the strength of stones? or is my flesh of brass?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%13%%Is not my help in me? and is wisdom driven quite from me?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%14%%To him that is afflicted pity should be shown from his friend; but he forsaketh the fear of the Almighty.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%15%%My brethren have dealt deceitfully as a brook, and as the stream of brooks they pass away;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%16%%Which are blackish by reason of the ice, and in which the snow is hid:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%17%%In the time when they become warm, they vanish: when it is hot, they are consumed out of their place.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%18%%The paths of their way are turned aside; they go to nothing, and perish.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%19%%The troops of Tema looked, the companies of Sheba waited for them.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%20%%They were confounded because they had hoped; they came thither, and were ashamed.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%21%%For now ye are nothing: ye see my casting down, and are afraid.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%22%%Did I say, Bring to me? or Give a reward for me of your substance?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%23%%Or, Deliver me from the enemy's hand? or, Redeem me from the hand of the mighty?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%24%%Teach me, and I will hold my tongue: and cause me to understand in what I have erred.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%25%%How forcible are right words! but what doth your arguing reprove?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%26%%Do ye imagine to reprove words, and the speeches of one that is desperate, which are as wind?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%27%%Yes, ye overwhelm the fatherless, and ye dig a pit for your friend.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%28%%Now therefore be content, look upon me; for it is evident to you if I lie.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%29%%Return, I pray you, let it not be iniquity; yes, return again, my righteousness is in it.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%6%%30%%Is there iniquity in my tongue? cannot my taste discern perverse things?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%1%%Is there not an appointed time to man upon earth? are not his days also like the days of a hireling?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%2%%As a servant earnestly desireth the shadow, and as a hireling looketh for the reward of his work;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%3%%So am I made to possess months of vanity, and wearisome nights are appointed to me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%4%%When I lie down, I say, When shall I arise, and the night be gone? and I am full of tossings to and fro to the dawning of the day.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%5%%My flesh is clothed with worms and clods of dust; my skin is broken and become lothsome.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%6%%My days are swifter than a weaver's shuttle, and are spent without hope.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%7%%O remember that my life is wind: my eye will no more see good.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%8%%The eye of him that hath seen me shall see me no more: thy eyes are upon me, and I am not.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%9%%As the cloud is consumed and vanisheth away: so he that goeth down to the grave shall come up no more.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%10%%He shall return no more to his house, neither shall his place know him any more.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%11%%Therefore I will not restrain my mouth; I will speak in the anguish of my spirit; I will complain in the bitterness of my soul.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%12%%Am I a sea, or a whale, that thou settest a watch over me?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%13%%When I say, My bed shall comfort me, my couch shall ease my complaint;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%14%%Then thou scarest me with dreams, and terrifiest me through visions:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%15%%So that my soul chooseth strangling, and death rather than my life.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%16%%I lothe it; I would not live always: let me alone; for my days are vanity.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%17%%What is man, that thou shouldst magnify him? and that thou shouldst set thy heart upon him?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%18%%And that thou shouldst visit him every morning, and try him every moment?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%19%%How long wilt thou not depart from me, nor let me alone till I swallow my spittle?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%20%%I have sinned; what shall I do to thee, O thou preserver of men? why hast thou set me as a mark against thee, so that I am a burden to myself?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%7%%21%%And why dost thou not pardon my transgression, and take away my iniquity? for now shall I sleep in the dust; and thou shalt seek me in the morning, but I shall not be.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%1%%Then answered Bildad the Shuhite, and said,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%2%%How long wilt thou speak these things? and how long shall the words of thy mouth be like a strong wind?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%3%%Doth God pervert judgment; or doth the Almighty pervert justice?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%4%%If thy children have sinned against him, and he hath cast them away for their transgression;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%5%%If thou wouldst seek to God betimes, and make thy supplication to the Almighty;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%6%%If thou wert pure and upright; surely now he would awake for thee, and make the habitation of thy righteousness prosperous.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%7%%Though thy beginning was small, yet thy latter end would greatly increase.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%8%%For inquire, I pray thee, of the former age, and prepare thyself to the search of their fathers:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%9%%(For we are but of yesterday, and know nothing, because our days upon earth are a shadow:)
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%10%%Will they not teach thee, and tell thee, and utter words out of their heart?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%11%%Can the rush grow without mire? can the flag grow without water?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%12%%Whilst it is yet in its greenness, and not cut down, it withereth before any other herb.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%13%%So are the paths of all that forget God; and the hypocrite's hope shall perish:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%14%%Whose hope shall be cut off, and whose trust shall be a spider's web.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%15%%He shall lean upon his house, but it shall not stand: he shall hold it fast, but it shall not endure.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%16%%He is green before the sun, and his branch shooteth forth in his garden.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%17%%His roots are wrapped about the heap, and seeth the place of stones.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%18%%If he shall destroy him from his place, then it shall deny him, saying, I have not seen thee.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%19%%Behold, this is the joy of his way, and out of the earth shall others grow.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%20%%Behold, God will not cast away a perfect man, neither will he help the evil doers:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%21%%Till he shall fill thy mouth with laughing, and thy lips with rejoicing.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%8%%22%%They that hate thee shall be clothed with shame; and the dwelling place of the wicked shall come to naught.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%1%%Then Job answered and said,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%2%%I know it to be so of a truth: but how should man be just with God?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%3%%If he will contend with him, he cannot answer him one of a thousand.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%4%%He is wise in heart, and mighty in strength: who hath hardened himself against him, and hath prospered?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%5%%Who removeth the mountains, and they know not: who overturneth them in his anger.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%6%%Who shaketh the earth out of her place, and its pillars tremble.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%7%%Who commandeth the sun, and it riseth not; and sealeth up the stars.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%8%%Who alone spreadeth out the heavens, and treadeth upon the waves of the sea.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%9%%Who maketh Arcturus, Orion, and Pleiades, and the chambers of the south.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%10%%Who doeth great things past finding out; yes, and wonders without number.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%11%%Lo, he goeth by me, and I see him not: he passeth on also, but I perceive him not.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%12%%Behold, he taketh away, who can hinder him? who will say to him, What doest thou?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%13%%If God will not withdraw his anger, the proud helpers do stoop under him.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%14%%How much less shall I answer him, and choose out my words to reason with him?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%15%%Whom, though I were righteous, yet would I not answer, but I would make supplication to my judge.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%16%%If I had called, and he had answered me; yet I would not believe that he had hearkened to my voice.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%17%%For he breaketh me with a tempest, and multiplieth my wounds without cause.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%18%%He will not suffer me to take my breath, but filleth me with bitterness.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%19%%If I speak of strength, lo, he is strong: and if of judgment, who shall set me a time to plead?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%20%%If I justify myself, my own mouth will condemn me: if I say, I am perfect, that also will prove me perverse.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%21%%Though I were perfect, yet would I not know my soul: I would despise my life.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%22%%This is one thing, therefore I said it, he destroyeth the perfect and the wicked.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%23%%If the scourge shall slay suddenly, he will laugh at the trial of the innocent.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%24%%The earth is given into the hand of the wicked: he covereth the faces of its judges; if not, where, and who is he?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%25%%Now my days are swifter than a post: they flee away, they see no good.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%26%%They are passed away as the swift ships: as the eagle that hasteth to the prey.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%27%%If I say, I will forget my complaint, I will leave off my heaviness, and comfort myself:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%28%%I am afraid of all my sorrows, I know that thou wilt not hold me innocent.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%29%%If I am wicked, why then do I labor in vain?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%30%%If I wash myself with snow water, and make my hands never so clean;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%31%%Yet wilt thou plunge me in the ditch, and my own clothes shall abhor me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%32%%For he is not a man, as I am, that I should answer him, and we should come together in judgment.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%33%%Neither is there any judge between us, that might lay his hand upon us both.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%34%%Let him take away his rod from me, and let not his fear terrify me:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%9%%35%%Then would I speak, and not fear him; but it is not so with me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%1%%My soul is weary of my life; I will leave my complaint upon myself; I will speak in the bitterness of my soul.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%2%%I will say to God, Do not condemn me; show me why thou contendest with me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%3%%Is it good to thee that thou shouldst oppress, that thou shouldst despise the work of thy hands, and shine upon the counsel of the wicked?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%4%%Hast thou eyes of flesh? or seest thou as man seeth?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%5%%Are thy days as the days of man? are thy years as man's days,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%6%%That thou inquirest after my iniquity, and searchest after my sin?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%7%%Thou knowest that I am not wicked; and there is none that can deliver out of thy hand.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%8%%Thy hands have made me and fashioned me in all my parts; yet thou dost destroy me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%9%%Remember, I beseech thee, that thou hast made me as the clay; and wilt thou bring me into dust again?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%10%%Hast thou not poured me out as milk, and curdled me like cheese?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%11%%Thou hast clothed me with skin and flesh, and hast fenced me with bones and sinews.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%12%%Thou hast granted me life and favor, and thy visitation hath preserved my spirit.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%13%%And these things hast thou hid in thy heart: I know that this is with thee.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%14%%If I sin, then thou markest me, and thou wilt not acquit me from my iniquity.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%15%%If I be wicked, woe to me; and if I be righteous, yet will I not lift up my head. I am full of confusion; therefore see thou my affliction;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%16%%For it increaseth. Thou huntest me as a fierce lion: and again thou showest thyself wonderful upon me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%17%%Thou renewest thy witnesses against me, and increasest thy indignation upon me; changes and war are against me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%18%%Why then hast thou brought me forth from the womb? O that I had expired, and no eye had seen me!
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%19%%I should have been as though I had not been; I should have been carried from the womb to the grave.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%20%%Are not my days few? cease then, and let me alone, that I may take comfort a little,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%21%%Before I go whence I shall not return, even to the land of darkness, and the shades of death;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%10%%22%%A land of darkness, as darkness itself; and of the shades of death, without any order, and where the light is as darkness.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%1%%Then answered Zophar the Naamathite, and said,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%2%%Should not the multitude of words be answered? and should a man full of talk be justified?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%3%%Should thy falsehoods make men hold their peace? and when thou mockest, shall no man make thee ashamed?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%4%%For thou hast said, My doctrine is pure, and I am clean in thy eyes.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%5%%But Oh that God would speak, and open his lips against thee;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%6%%And that he would show thee the secrets of wisdom, that they are double to that which is! Know therefore that God exacteth of thee less than thy iniquity deserveth.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%7%%Canst thou by searching find out God? canst thou find out the Almighty to perfection?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%8%%It is as high as heaven; what canst thou do? deeper than hell; what canst thou know?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%9%%The measure of it is longer than the earth, and broader than the sea.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%10%%If he shall cut off, and shut up, or gather together, then who can hinder him?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%11%%For he knoweth vain men: he seeth wickedness also; will he not then consider it?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%12%%For vain man would be wise, though man is born like a wild ass's colt.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%13%%If thou preparest thy heart, and stretchest out thy hands towards him;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%14%%If iniquity is in thy hand, put it far away, and let not wickedness dwell in thy tabernacles.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%15%%For then shalt thou lift up thy face without spot; yes, thou shalt be steadfast, and shalt not fear:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%16%%Because thou shalt forget thy misery, and remember it as waters that pass away:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%17%%And thy age shall be clearer than the noon-day: thou shalt shine forth, thou shalt be as the morning.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%18%%And thou shalt be secure, because there is hope; yes, thou shalt dig about thee, and thou shalt take thy rest in safety.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%19%%Also thou shalt lie down, and none shall make thee afraid; yes, many shall make suit to thee.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%11%%20%%But the eyes of the wicked shall fail, and they shall not escape, and their hope shall be as the expiration of the breath.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%1%%And Job answered and said,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%2%%No doubt but ye are the people, and wisdom shall die with you.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%3%%But I have understanding as well as you; I am not inferior to you: yes, who knoweth not such things as these?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%4%%I am as one mocked by his neighbor, who calleth upon God, and he answereth him: the just upright man is derided.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%5%%He that is ready to slip with his feet is as a lamp despised in the thought of him that is at ease.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%6%%The tabernacles of robbers prosper, and they that provoke God are secure; into whose hand God bringeth abundantly.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%7%%But ask now the beasts, and they shall teach thee; and the fowls of the air, and they shall tell thee:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%8%%Or speak to the earth, and it shall teach thee: and the fishes of the sea shall declare to thee.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%9%%Who knoweth not in all these that the hand of the LORD hath wrought this?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%10%%In whose hand is the soul of every living thing, and the breath of all mankind.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%11%%Doth not the ear try words? and the mouth taste its food?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%12%%With the ancient is wisdom; and in length of days understanding.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%13%%With him is wisdom and strength, he hath counsel and understanding.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%14%%Behold, he breaketh down, and it cannot be built again: he shutteth up a man, and there can be no opening.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%15%%Behold, he withholdeth the waters, and they dry up: also he sendeth them out, and they overturn the earth.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%16%%With him is strength and wisdom: the deceived and the deceiver are his.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%17%%He leadeth counselors away spoiled, and maketh the judges fools.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%18%%He looseth the bond of kings, and girdeth their loins with a girdle.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%19%%He leadeth princes away spoiled, and overthroweth the mighty.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%20%%He removeth away the speech of the trusty, and taketh away the understanding of the aged.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%21%%He poureth contempt upon princes, and weakeneth the strength of the mighty.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%22%%He revealeth deep things out of darkness, and bringeth to light the shades of death.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%23%%He increaseth nations, and destroyeth them: he enlargeth nations, and straiteneth them again.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%24%%He taketh away the heart of the chief of the people of the earth, and causeth them to wander in a wilderness where there is no way.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%12%%25%%They grope in the dark without light, and he maketh them to stagger like a drunken man.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%1%%Lo, my eye hath seen all this, my ear hath heard and understood it.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%2%%What ye know, the same do I know also: I am not inferior to you.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%3%%Surely I would speak to the Almighty, and I desire to reason with God.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%4%%But ye are forgers of lies, ye are all physicians of no value.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%5%%O that ye would altogether hold your peace and it would be your wisdom.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%6%%Hear now my reasoning, and hearken to the pleadings of my lips.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%7%%Will ye speak wickedly for God? and talk deceitfully for him?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%8%%Will ye accept his person? will ye contend for God?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%9%%Is it good that he should search you out? or as one man mocketh another, do ye so mock him?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%10%%He will surely reprove you, if ye do secretly accept persons.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%11%%Shall not his excellence make you afraid? and his dread fall upon you?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%12%%Your remembrances are like to ashes, your bodies to bodies of clay.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%13%%Hold your peace, let me alone, that I may speak, and let come on me what will.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%14%%Why do I take my flesh in my teeth, and put my life in my hand?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%15%%Though he shall slay me, yet will I trust in him: but I will maintain my own ways before him.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%16%%He also shall be my salvation: for a hypocrite shall not come before him.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%17%%Hear diligently my speech, and my declaration with your ears.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%18%%Behold now, I have ordered my cause; I know that I shall be justified.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%19%%Who is he that will plead with me? for now, if I hold my tongue, I shall expire.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%20%%Only do not two things to me: then will I not hide myself from thee.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%21%%Withdraw thy hand far from me: and let not thy dread make me afraid.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%22%%Then call thou, and I will answer: or let me speak, and answer thou me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%23%%How many are my iniquities and sins? make me to know my transgression and my sin.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%24%%Why hidest thou thy face, and holdest me for thy enemy?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%25%%Wilt thou break a leaf driven to and fro? and wilt thou pursue the dry stubble?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%26%%For thou writest bitter things against me, and makest me to possess the iniquities of my youth.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%27%%Thou puttest my feet also in the stocks, and lookest narrowly to all my paths; thou settest a print upon the heels of my feet.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%13%%28%%And he, as a rotten thing, consumeth, as a garment that is moth-eaten.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%1%%Man that is born of a woman is of few days, and full of trouble.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%2%%He cometh forth like a flower, and is cut down: he fleeth also as a shadow, and continueth not.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%3%%And dost thou open thy eyes upon such one, and bring me into judgment with thee?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%4%%Who can bring a clean thing out of an unclean? not one.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%5%%Seeing his days are determined, the number of his months is with thee, thou hast appointed his bounds that he cannot pass;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%6%%Turn from him, that he may rest, till he shall accomplish, as a hireling, his day.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%7%%For there is hope of a tree, if it is cut down, that it will sprout again, and that its tender branch will not cease.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%8%%Though its root shall become old in the earth, and its stock die in the ground;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%9%%Yet through the scent of water it will bud, and bring forth boughs like a plant.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%10%%But man dieth, and wasteth away: yes, man yieldeth his breath, and where is he?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%11%%As the waters fail from the sea, and the flood decayeth and drieth up:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%12%%So man lieth down, and riseth not: till the heavens shall be no more, they shall not awake, nor be raised out of their sleep.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%13%%O that thou wouldst hide me in the grave, that thou wouldst keep me secret, until thy wrath is past, that thou wouldst appoint me a set time, and remember me!
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%14%%If a man dieth, shall he live again? all the days of my appointed time will I wait, till my change shall come.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%15%%Thou shalt call, and I will answer thee: thou wilt have a desire to the work of thy hands.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%16%%For now thou numberest my steps: dost thou not watch over my sin?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%17%%My transgression is sealed up in a bag, and thou sewest up my iniquity.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%18%%And surely the mountain falling cometh to naught, and the rock is removed out of its place.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%19%%The waters wear the stones: thou washest away the things which grow out of the dust of the earth; and thou destroyest the hope of man.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%20%%Thou prevailest for ever against him, and he passeth: thou changest his countenance, and sendest him away.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%21%%His sons come to honor, and he knoweth it not; and they are brought low, but he perceiveth it not of them.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%14%%22%%But his flesh upon him shall have pain, and his soul within him shall mourn.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%1%%Then answered Eliphaz the Temanite, and said,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%2%%Should a wise men utter vain knowledge, and fill his belly with the east wind?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%3%%Should he reason with unprofitable talk? or with speeches with which he can do no good?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%4%%Yes, thou castest off fear, and restrainest prayer before God.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%5%%For thy mouth uttereth thy iniquity, and thou choosest the tongue of the crafty.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%6%%Thy own mouth condemneth thee, and not I: yes, thy own lips testify against thee.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%7%%Art thou the first man that was born? or wast thou made before the hills?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%8%%Hast thou heard the secret of God? and dost thou restrain wisdom to thyself?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%9%%What knowest thou that we know not? what understandest thou, which is not in us?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%10%%With us are both the gray headed and very aged men, much older than thy father.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%11%%Are the consolations of God small with thee? is there any secret thing with thee?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%12%%Why doth thy heart carry thee away? and what do thy eyes wink at,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%13%%That thou turnest thy spirit against God, and lettest such words go out of thy mouth?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%14%%What is man, that he should be clean? and he who is born of a woman, that he should be righteous?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%15%%Behold, he putteth no trust in his saints; yes, the heavens are not clean in his sight.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%16%%How much more abominable and filthy is man, who drinketh iniquity like water?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%17%%I will show thee, hear me; and that which I have seen, I will declare;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%18%%Which wise men have told from their fathers, and have not hid it:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%19%%To whom alone the earth was given, and no stranger passed among them.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%20%%The wicked man travaileth with pain all his days, and the number of years is hidden to the oppressor.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%21%%A dreadful sound is in his ears: in prosperity the destroyer shall come upon him.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%22%%He believeth not that he shall return out of darkness, and he is waited for by the sword.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%23%%He wandereth abroad for bread, saying, Where is it? he knoweth that the day of darkness is ready at his hand.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%24%%Trouble and anguish shall make him afraid; they shall prevail against him, as a king ready to the battle.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%25%%For he stretcheth out his hand against God, and strengtheneth himself against the Almighty.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%26%%He runneth upon him, even on his neck, upon the thick bosses of his bucklers:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%27%%Because he covereth his face with his fatness, and maketh collops of fat on his flanks.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%28%%And he dwelleth in desolate cities, and in houses which no man inhabiteth, which are ready to become heaps.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%29%%He shall not be rich, neither shall his substance continue, neither shall he prolong the perfection of it upon the earth.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%30%%He shall not depart out of darkness; the flame shall dry up his branches, and by the breath of his mouth shall he go away.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%31%%Let not him that is deceived trust in vanity: for vanity shall be his recompense.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%32%%It shall be accomplished before his time, and his branch shall not be green.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%33%%He shall shake off his unripe grape as the vine, and shall cast off his flower as the olive.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%34%%For the congregation of hypocrites shall be desolate, and fire shall consume the tabernacles of bribery.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%15%%35%%They conceive mischief, and bring forth vanity, and their belly prepareth deceit.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%1%%Then Job answered and said,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%2%%I have heard many such things: miserable comforters are ye all.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%3%%Shall vain words have an end? or what emboldeneth thee that thou answerest?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%4%%I also could speak as ye do: if your soul were in my soul's stead, I could heap up words against you, and shake my head at you.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%5%%But I would strengthen you with my mouth and the moving of my lips should assuage your grief.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%6%%Though I speak, my grief is not assuaged: and though I forbear, what am I eased?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%7%%But now he hath made me weary: thou hast made desolate all my company.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%8%%And thou hast filled me with wrinkles, which is a witness against me: and my leanness rising up in me beareth witness to my face.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%9%%He teareth me in his wrath, who hateth me: he gnasheth upon me with his teeth; my enemy sharpeneth his eyes upon me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%10%%They have gaped upon me with their mouth; they have smitten me upon the cheek reproachfully; they have gathered themselves against me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%11%%God hath delivered me to the ungodly, and turned me over into the hands of the wicked.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%12%%I was at ease, but he hath broken me asunder: he hath also taken me by my neck, and shaken me to pieces, and set me up for his mark.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%13%%His archers encompass me; he cleaveth my reins asunder, and doth not spare; he poureth out my gall upon the ground.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%14%%He breaketh me with breach upon breach, he runneth upon me like a giant.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%15%%I have sewed sackcloth upon my skin, and defiled my horn in the dust.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%16%%My face is foul with weeping, and on my eyelids are the shades of death;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%17%%Not for any injustice in my hands: also my prayer is pure.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%18%%O earth, cover not thou my blood, and let my cry have no place.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%19%%Also now, behold, my witness is in heaven, and my record is on high.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%20%%My friends scorn me: but my eye poureth out tears to God.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%21%%O that one might plead for a man with God, as a man pleadeth for his neighbor!
1000005%%Job%%OT%%16%%22%%When a few years are come, then I shall go the way whence I shall not return.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%17%%1%%My breath is corrupt, my days are extinct, the graves are ready for me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%17%%2%%Are there not mockers with me? and doth not my eye continue in their provocation?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%17%%3%%Lay down now, put me in a surety with thee; who is he that will strike hands with me?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%17%%4%%For thou hast hid their heart from understanding: therefore shalt thou not exalt them.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%17%%5%%He that speaketh flattery to his friends, even the eyes of his children shall fail.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%17%%6%%He hath made me also a by-word of the people; and in former time I was as a tabret.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%17%%7%%My eye also is dim by reason of sorrow, and all my members are as a shade.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%17%%8%%Upright men shall be astonished at this, and the innocent shall stir up himself against the hypocrite.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%17%%9%%The righteous also shall hold on his way, and he that hath clean hands shall be stronger and stronger.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%17%%10%%But as for you all, do ye return, and come now: for I cannot find one wise man among you.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%17%%11%%My days are past, my purposes are broken off, even the thoughts of my heart.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%17%%12%%They change the night into day: the light is short because of darkness.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%17%%13%%If I wait, the grave is my house: I have made my bed in the darkness.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%17%%14%%I have said to corruption, Thou art my father: to the worm, Thou art my mother, and my sister.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%17%%15%%And where is now my hope? as for my hope, who will see it?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%17%%16%%They shall go down to the bars of the pit, when our rest together is in the dust.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%1%%Then answered Bildad the Shuhite, and said,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%2%%How long will it be ere ye make an end of words? mark, and afterwards we will speak.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%3%%Why are we counted as beasts, and reputed vile in your sight?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%4%%He teareth himself in his anger: shall the earth be forsaken for thee? and shall the rock be removed out of its place?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%5%%Yes, the light of the wicked shall be put out, and the spark of his fire shall not shine.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%6%%The light shall be dark in his tabernacle, and his candle shall be put out with him.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%7%%The steps of his strength shall be straitened, and his own counsel shall cast him down.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%8%%For he is cast into a net by his own feet, and he walketh upon a snare.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%9%%The gin shall take him by the heel, and the robber shall prevail against him.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%10%%The snare is laid for him in the ground, and a trap for him in the way.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%11%%Terrors shall make him afraid on every side, and shall drive him to his feet.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%12%%His strength shall be hunger-bitten, and destruction shall be ready at his side.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%13%%It shall devour the strength of his skin: even the first-born of death shall devour his strength.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%14%%His confidence shall be rooted out of his tabernacle, and it shall bring him to the king of terrors.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%15%%It shall dwell in his tabernacle, because it is none of his: brimstone shall be scattered upon his habitation.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%16%%His roots shall be dried up beneath, and above shall his branch be cut off.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%17%%His remembrance shall perish from the earth, and he shall have no name in the street.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%18%%He shall be driven from light into darkness, and chased out of the world.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%19%%He shall neither have son nor nephew among his people, nor any remaining in his dwellings.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%20%%They that come after him shall be astonished at his day, as they that went before were affrighted.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%18%%21%%Surely such are the dwellings of the wicked, and this is the place of him that knoweth not God.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%1%%Then Job answered and said,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%2%%How long will ye vex my soul, and break me in pieces with words?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%3%%These ten times have ye reproached me: ye are not ashamed that ye make yourselves strange to me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%4%%And be it indeed that I have erred, my error remaineth with myself.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%5%%If indeed ye will magnify yourselves against me, and plead against me my reproach:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%6%%Know now that God hath overthrown me, and hath encompassed me with his net.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%7%%Behold, I cry out of wrong, but I am not heard: I cry aloud, but there is no judgment.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%8%%He hath fenced up my way that I cannot pass, and he hath set darkness in my paths.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%9%%He hath stripped me of my glory, and taken the crown from my head.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%10%%He hath destroyed me on every side, and I am gone: and my hope hath he removed like a tree.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%11%%He hath also kindled his wrath against me, and he counteth me to him as one of his enemies.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%12%%His troops come together, and raise up their way against me, and encamp around my tabernacle.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%13%%He hath put my brethren far from me, and my acquaintance are verily estranged from me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%14%%My kinsmen have failed, and my familiar friends have forgotten me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%15%%They that dwell in my house, and my maids, count me for a stranger: I am an alien in their sight.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%16%%I called my servant, and he gave me no answer; I entreated him with my mouth.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%17%%My breath is strange to my wife, though I entreated for the children's sake of my own body.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%18%%Yes, young children despised me; I arose, and they spoke against me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%19%%All my intimate friends abhorred me: and they whom I loved are turned against me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%20%%My bone cleaveth to my skin and to my flesh, and I have escaped with the skin of my teeth.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%21%%Have pity upon me, have pity upon me, O ye my friends; for the hand of God hath touched me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%22%%Why do ye persecute me as God, and are not satisfied with my flesh?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%23%%Oh that my words were now written! oh that they were printed in a book!
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%24%%That they were graven with an iron pen in lead, in the rock for ever!
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%25%%For I know that my redeemer liveth, and that he will stand at the latter day upon the earth:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%26%%And though after my skin worms destroy this body, yet in my flesh shall I see God:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%27%%Whom I shall see for myself, and my eyes shall behold, and not another; though my reins be consumed within me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%28%%But ye would say, Why persecute we him, seeing the root of the matter is found in me?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%19%%29%%Be ye afraid of the sword: for wrath bringeth the punishments of the sword, that ye may know there is a judgment.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%1%%Then answered Zophar the Naamathite, and said,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%2%%Therefore do my thoughts cause me to answer, and for this I make haste.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%3%%I have heard the check of my reproach, and the spirit of my understanding causeth me to answer.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%4%%Knowest thou not this of old, since man was placed upon earth,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%5%%That the triumphing of the wicked is short, and the joy of the hypocrite but for a moment?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%6%%Though his excellence shall mount up to the heavens, and his head reach to the clouds;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%7%%Yet he shall perish for ever like his own dung: they who have seen him shall say, Where is he?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%8%%He shall fly away as a dream, and will not be found: yea, he shall be chased away as a vision of the night.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%9%%The eye also which saw him shall see him no more; neither shall his place any more behold him.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%10%%His children shall seek to please the poor, and his hands shall restore their goods.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%11%%His bones are full of the sin of his youth, which shall lie down with him in the dust.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%12%%Though wickedness may be sweet in his mouth, though he may hide it under his tongue;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%13%%Though he may spare it, and forsake it not; but keep it still within his mouth:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%14%%Yet his food in his bowels is turned, it is the gall of asps within him.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%15%%He hath swallowed down riches, and he shall vomit them up again: God shall cast them out of his belly.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%16%%He shall suck the poison of asps: the viper's tongue shall slay him.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%17%%He shall not see the river, the floods, the brooks of honey and buttermilk.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%18%%That which he labored for shall he restore, and shall not swallow it: according to his substance shall the restitution be, and he shall not rejoice in it.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%19%%Because he hath oppressed and hath forsaken the poor; because he hath violently taken away a house which he did not build.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%20%%Surely he shall not feel quietness in his belly, he shall not save of that which he desired.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%21%%There shall none of his food be left; therefore shall no man look for his goods.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%22%%In the fullness of his sufficiency he shall be in straits: every hand of the wicked shall come upon him.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%23%%When he is about to fill his belly, God shall cast the fury of his wrath upon him, and shall rain it upon him while he is eating.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%24%%He shall flee from the iron weapon, and the bow of steel shall strike him through.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%25%%It is drawn, and cometh out of the body; yes, the glittering sword cometh out of his gall: terrors are upon him.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%26%%All darkness shall be hid in his secret places: a fire not blown shall consume him; it shall go ill with him that is left in his tabernacle.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%27%%The heaven shall reveal his iniquity; and the earth shall rise up against him.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%28%%The increase of his house shall depart, and his goods shall flow away in the day of his wrath.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%20%%29%%This is the portion of a wicked man from God, and the heritage appointed to him by God.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%1%%But Job answered and said,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%2%%Hear diligently my speech, and let this be your consolations.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%3%%Suffer me that I may speak; and after I have spoken, mock on.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%4%%As for me, is my complaint to man? and if it were so, why should not my spirit be troubled?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%5%%Mark me, and be astonished, and lay your hand upon your mouth.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%6%%Even when I remember I am afraid, and trembling taketh hold on my flesh.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%7%%Why do the wicked live, become old, and, are mighty in power?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%8%%Their seed is established in their sight with them, and their offspring before their eyes.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%9%%Their houses are safe from fear, neither is the rod of God upon them.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%10%%Their bull gendereth, and faileth not; their cow calveth, and casteth not her calf.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%11%%They send forth their little ones like a flock, and their children dance.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%12%%They take the timbrel and harp, and rejoice at the sound of the organ.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%13%%They spend their days in wealth, and in a moment go down to the grave.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%14%%Therefore they say to God, Depart from us; for we desire not the knowledge of thy ways.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%15%%What is the Almighty, that we should serve him? and what profit should we have, if we pray to him?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%16%%Lo, their good is not in their hand: the counsel of the wicked is far from me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%17%%How oft is the candle of the wicked put out? and how oft cometh their destruction upon them? God distributeth sorrows in his anger.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%18%%They are as stubble before the wind, and as chaff that the storm carrieth away.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%19%%God layeth up his iniquity for his children: he rewardeth him, and he shall know it.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%20%%His eyes shall see his destruction, and he shall drink of the wrath of the Almighty.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%21%%For what pleasure hath he in his house after him, when the number of his months is cut off in the midst?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%22%%Shall any teach God knowledge? seeing he judgeth those that are high.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%23%%One dieth in his full strength, being wholly at ease and quiet.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%24%%His breasts are full of milk, and his bones are moistened with marrow.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%25%%And another dieth in the bitterness of his soul, and never eateth with pleasure.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%26%%They shall lie down alike in the dust, and the worms shall cover them.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%27%%Behold, I know your thoughts, and the devices which ye wrongfully imagine against me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%28%%For ye say, Where is the house of the prince? and where are the dwelling places of the wicked?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%29%%Have ye not asked them that go by the way? and do ye not know their tokens,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%30%%That the wicked is reserved to the day of destruction? they will be brought forth to the day of wrath.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%31%%Who shall declare his way to his face? and who shall repay him what he hath done?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%32%%Yet he shall be brought to the grave, and shall remain in the tomb.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%33%%The clods of the valley will be sweet to him, and every man will draw after him, as there are innumerable before him.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%21%%34%%How then comfort ye me in vain, seeing in your answers there remaineth falsehood?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%1%%Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%2%%Can a man be profitable to God, as he that is wise may be profitable to himself?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%3%%Is it any pleasure to the Almighty, that thou art righteous? or is it gain to him, that thou makest thy ways perfect?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%4%%Will he reprove thee for fear of thee? will he enter with thee into judgment?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%5%%Is not thy wickedness great? and thy iniquities infinite?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%6%%For thou hast taken a pledge from thy brother for naught, and stripped the naked of their clothing.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%7%%Thou hast not given water to the weary to drink, and thou hast withheld bread from the hungry.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%8%%But as for the mighty man, he had the earth; and the honorable man dwelt in it.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%9%%Thou hast sent widows away empty, and the arms of the fatherless have been broken.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%10%%Therefore snares are around thee, and sudden fear troubleth thee;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%11%%Or darkness, that thou canst not see; and abundance of waters cover thee.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%12%%Is not God in the hight of heaven? and behold the hight of the stars, how high they are!
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%13%%And thou sayest, How doth God know? can he judge through the dark cloud?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%14%%Thick clouds are a covering to him, that he seeth not; and he walketh in the circuit of heaven.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%15%%Hast thou marked the old way which wicked men have trodden?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%16%%Who were cut down out of time, whose foundation was overflowed with a flood!
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%17%%Who said to God, depart from us: and what can the Almighty do for them!
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%18%%Yet he filled their houses with good things: but the counsel of the wicked is far from me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%19%%The righteous see it, and are glad: and the innocent deride them.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%20%%Whereas our substance is not cut down, but the remnant of them the fire consumeth.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%21%%Acquaint now thyself with him, and be at peace: by this good shall come to thee.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%22%%Receive, I pray thee, the law from his mouth, and lay up his words in thy heart.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%23%%If thou shalt return to the Almighty, thou shalt be built up, thou shalt put away iniquity far from thy tabernacles.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%24%%Then shalt thou lay up gold as dust, and the gold of Ophir as the stones of the brooks.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%25%%Yea, the Almighty shall be thy defense and thou shalt have plenty of silver.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%26%%For then shalt thou have thy delight in the Almighty, and shalt lift up thy face to God.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%27%%Thou shalt make thy prayer to him, and he shall hear thee, and thou shalt pay thy vows.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%28%%Thou shalt also decree a thing, and it shall be established to thee: and the light shall shine upon thy ways.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%29%%When men are cast down, then thou shalt say, There is exaltation; and he shall save the humble person.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%22%%30%%He shall deliver the island of the innocent: and it is delivered by the pureness of thy hands.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%1%%Then Job answered and said,
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%2%%Even to-day is my complaint bitter: my stroke is heavier than my groaning.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%3%%Oh that I knew where I might find him! that I might come even to his seat!
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%4%%I would order my cause before him, and fill my mouth with arguments.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%5%%I would know the words which he would answer me, and understand what he would say to me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%6%%Would he plead against me with his great power? No; but he would put strength in me.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%7%%There the righteous might dispute with him; so should I be delivered for ever from my judge.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%8%%Behold, I go forward, but he is not there; and backward, but I cannot perceive him:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%9%%On the left hand, where he doth work, but I cannot behold him: he hideth himself on the right hand, that I cannot see him:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%10%%But he knoweth the way that I take: when he hath tried me, I shall come forth as gold.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%11%%My foot hath held his steps, his way have I kept, and not declined.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%12%%Neither have I gone back from the commandment of his lips; I have esteemed the words of his mouth more than my necessary food.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%13%%But he is in one mind, and who can turn him? and what his soul desireth, even that he doeth.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%14%%For he performeth the thing that is appointed for me: and many such things are with him.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%15%%Therefore am I troubled at his presence: when I consider, I am afraid of him.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%16%%For God maketh my heart soft, and the Almighty troubleth me:
1000005%%Job%%OT%%23%%17%%Because I was not cut off before the darkness, neither hath he covered the darkness from my face.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%1%%Why, seeing times are not hid from the Almighty, do they that know him not see his days?
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%2%%Some remove the landmarks: they violently take away flocks, and their feed.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%3%%They drive away the ass of the fatherless, they take the widow's ox for a pledge.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%4%%They turn the needy out of the way: the poor of the earth hide themselves together.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%5%%Behold, as wild asses in the desert, they go forth to their work; rising betimes for a prey: the wilderness yieldeth food for them and for their children.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%6%%They reap every one his corn in the field: and they gather the vintage of the wicked.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%7%%They cause the naked to lodge without clothing, that they have no covering in the cold.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%8%%They are wet with the showers of the mountains, and embrace the rock for want of a shelter.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%9%%They pluck the fatherless from the breast, and take a pledge of the poor.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%10%%They cause him to go naked without clothing, and they take away the sheaf from the hungry;
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%11%%Who make oil within their walls, and tread their wine-presses, and suffer thirst.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%12%%Men groan from out of the city, and the soul of the wounded crieth out: yet God layeth not folly to them.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%13%%They are of those that rebel against the light; they know not its ways, nor abide in its paths.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%14%%The murderer rising with the light killeth the poor and needy, and in the night is as a thief.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%15%%The eye also of the adulterer waiteth for the twilight, saying, No eye shall see me: and disguiseth his face.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%16%%In the dark they dig through houses, which they had marked for themselves in the day-time: they know not the light.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%17%%For the morning is to them even as the shades of death: if one knoweth them, they are in the terrors of the shades of death.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%18%%He is swift as the waters; their portion is cursed in the earth: he beholdeth not the way of the vineyards.
1000005%%Job%%OT%%24%%19%%Drouth and heat consume the snow-waters: so doth the grave those who have sinned.
